description: From Old French frequent, from Latin frequens (“crowded, crammed, frequent, repeated, etc.”), from Proto-Indo-European *bhrek- (“to cram together”).

adjectives.description: frequent (comparative more frequent or frequenter, superlative most frequent or frequentest)

examples: I take frequent breaks so I don't get too tired.
There are frequent trains to the beach available.
I am a frequent visitor to that city.

entries.meaning: Addicted to any course of conduct; inclined to indulge in any practice; habitual; persistent.

examples: 'Tis Caesar's will to have a frequent senate.
'Tis frequent in the city he hath subdued / The Catti and the Daci.

description: From Old French frequenter, from Latin frequentare (“to fill, crowd, visit often, do or use often, etc.”), from frequens (“frequent, crowded”).

verbs.description: frequent (third-person singular simple present frequents, present participle frequenting, simple past and past participle frequented)

examples: I used to frequent that restaurant.
